study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Moringa oleifera seeds (MOS) in reducing metallic trace elements (MTEs) in domestic wastewater through a prototype wastewater treatment plant.
results_summary: The addition of MOS significantly reduced MTE concentrations in wastewater, with reductions ranging from 13% to 93% for various elements, proving MOS as effective as chemical coagulants like lime and ferric iron. The treated wastewater met UN-EP standards for safe reuse in irrigation.
population_specificity: Domestic wastewater samples.
effective_dosage: 300 mg·L⁻¹ in F0 (septic tank), 50 mg·L⁻¹ in F1 (bacterial filter), and 50 mg·L⁻¹ in F2 (infiltration well).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate Moringa oleifera-derived compounds for their potential to block EGFR and VEGFR-2 receptors as dual-acting drugs for NSCLC treatment.
results_summary: Five Moringa-derived compounds (hesperetin, gossypetin, quercetin, gallocatechin, and epigallocatechin) showed strong binding affinity to EGFR and VEGFR-2, outperforming control drugs in virtual screening, molecular docking, and dynamics simulations. Hesperetin, gossypetin, and quercetagetin emerged as the most promising candidates for dual-targeting therapy.
population_specificity: In silico study (no human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the toxicological profile of an aqueous extract of Moringa oleifera leaves after 13 weeks of oral administration in mice.
results_summary: The study found that Moringa extract at 250 and 500 mg/kg did not significantly affect body weight, food intake, or hematological/histological parameters, but 1000 mg/kg reduced food intake and body weight and increased liver enzymes. The extract significantly lowered serum lipid profiles in mice.
population_specificity: Female and male mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to isolate and characterize a fibrinolytic protease from Moringa oleifera leaves to evaluate its potential as a natural therapy for dissolving blood clots.
results_summary: The isolated protease demonstrated significant fibrinolytic activity, solubilizing 96.41% of blood clots in vitro under optimal conditions (pH 8.0, 37°C, 50 µg protein). The study confirmed its fibrin hydrolysis and clot-dissolving potential, suggesting it as a promising natural alternative for thrombosis treatment.
population_specificity: In-vitro study (no human or animal subjects specified).
effective_dosage: 50 µg protein for optimal fibrinolytic activity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the physicochemical properties and biological activities of Moringa peregrina extract-synthesized copper oxide nanoparticles (CuO NPs) and their composite with graphene oxide (CuO-GO) for potential biomedical applications.
results_summary: The study found that the CuO-GO nanocomposite exhibited superior cytotoxicity against MCF-7 cancer cells with minimal effects on normal NIH/3T3 cells, as well as potent antibacterial activity against Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Staphylococcus aureus, demonstrating selective cytotoxicity and synergistic effects.
population_specificity: In vitro testing on MCF-7 (human breast cancer cells) and NIH/3T3 (normal mouse fibroblast cells), as well as bacterial strains Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Staphylococcus aureus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effects of Moringa oleifera leaf extract on liver histopathology, glucose, and lipid metabolism, particularly in the context of NAFLD.
results_summary: The study found that Moringa oleifera leaf extract significantly improved liver histopathological features, glucose, and lipid metabolism in animal models, with a favorable safety profile for human health.
population_specificity: Animal sample models (specific species not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the proportion and determinants of fresh Moringa stenopetala leaf intake among pregnant women in the Gamo zone, Ethiopia.
results_summary: Nearly half (49.6%) of pregnant women consumed fresh Moringa leaves, with factors like younger age, rural residence, antenatal care attendance, contraceptive use history, and knowledge of Moringa's benefits positively influencing consumption.
population_specificity: Pregnant women in the Gamo zone, south Ethiopia.
study_duration: Dietary history assessed over the last 30 days before data collection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether incorporating moringa leaf extract into edible films enhances their physicochemical and functional characteristics, particularly antioxidant activity.
results_summary: The study found that edible films with 3% moringa leaf extract exhibited moderate antioxidant activity (IC50 of 135.074 ppm), improved tensile strength, elasticity, and biodegradability, and degraded within 14 days.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on edible films).
effective_dosage: 3% (v/v based on total volume of 100 mL) moringa leaf extract.
study_duration: Not specified (shelf life was five days at ambient temperature).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the research trend related to Moringa oleifera treatment for livestock embryos, focusing on frequently used keywords and citation patterns.
results_summary: The study found no research on Moringa oleifera for treating sick livestock embryos, no mention of ruminant-type animals other than cows in keywords, and low citation rates for the sampled papers.
population_specificity: Livestock embryos (no specific species beyond "cow" mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of Moringa oleifera seed proteins combined with biochar for treating greywater in rural Kenyan households.
results_summary: The study found that Moringa oleifera seed proteins significantly reduced contaminants in greywater, including colour (43-67%), turbidity (91-98%), and surfactants (89-93%), though total organic carbon and dissolved solids increased.
population_specificity: Rural households in Kwale and Siaya counties, Kenya.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether ethanolic Moringa Oleifera extract (MOE) loaded into niosomes (MOE-NIO) could protect against doxorubicin-induced cardiotoxicity in rats.
results_summary: MOE-NIO mitigated doxorubicin-induced cardiotoxicity by reducing oxidative stress, inflammation, and apoptosis markers while enhancing antioxidant status. It also modulated key signaling pathways (NF-kB, p38 MAPK, Nrf2) in cardiac tissue.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the biochemical and histological effects of Moringa oleifera leaf extract against valproate-induced kidney damage in rats.
results_summary: Moringa extract attenuated valproate-induced kidney damage by reducing oxidative stress biomarkers, inflammatory proteins, and histological damage while restoring antioxidant enzyme activities and glutathione levels.
population_specificity: Female Sprague-Dawley rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anticancer, anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and antibacterial properties of Moringa seed extract (MSE) and its potential mechanisms of action.
results_summary: MSE demonstrated potent anticancer effects against Caco-2, MDA, and HepG-2 cells with high selectivity for tumor cells over normal cells, induced apoptosis, and caused cell cycle arrest. It also exhibited strong anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and broad-spectrum antibacterial activity.
population_specificity: In vitro study using human cancer cell lines (Caco-2, MDA, HepG-2) and normal human cells, as well as bacterial strains (Staphylococcus aureus, Salmonella typhimurium, Escherichia coli).
effective_dosage: IC50 values of 9.15 ± 1.18, 4.85 ± 0.11, and 7.36 ± 0.22 µg/mL for cancer cells; MIC values of 1.25 mg/mL, 1.23 mg/mL, and 22.5 mg/mL for bacterial strains.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate glucomoringin from Moringa oleifera as a potential therapeutic agent for Alzheimer's disease using computational analysis.
results_summary: Molecular docking showed strong binding to I-1β, and pharmacokinetic analysis indicated cytochrome P450 enzyme inhibition. Toxicological predictions affirmed safety, and bioactivity assessments suggested versatility in modulating key pathways.
population_specificity: In silico (computational) study, no human or animal subjects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the molecular mechanisms by which Moringa oleifera leaf extract (Mor) and/or telmisartan (Telm) alleviate carbon tetrachloride (CCl4)-induced liver fibrosis in rats.
results_summary: Mor/Telm treatment significantly reduced liver fibrosis markers (ALT, AST, NF-κB, TNF-α, TGF-β1, caspase-3), downregulated HDAC2 and p-SMAD3, and upregulated SMAD7 and PPARγ expression, demonstrating hepatoprotective effects. Histopathological improvements were also observed.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley rats with CCl4-induced liver fibrosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the genoprotective activity and safety of Moringa oleifera leaf extracts against cyclophosphamide-induced genotoxicity in Swiss albino mice.
results_summary: Moringa oleifera extracts showed no significant genotoxic effects on somatic and germ cells and demonstrated potential chemoprotective properties by inhibiting DNA damage caused by cyclophosphamide.
population_specificity: Swiss albino mice
effective_dosage: 100, 200, or 400 mg/kg body weight administered orally daily
interactions: Cyclophosphamide (50 mg/kg body weight intraperitoneally daily for 5 days)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of chemically activated Moringa oleifera seed biomass (MOSB) as a biosorbent for removing progesterone (PGT) from synthetic wastewater.
results_summary: The study found that MOSB effectively adsorbed PGT with optimal conditions at 86.8 min, 500 μg L-1 PGT concentration, 298 K, and 0.1 g adsorbent dosage. The process was spontaneous, exothermic, and pH-independent, with a maximal monolayer biosorption capacity of 135.8 μg g-1.
population_specificity: Synthetic wastewater (not human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Moringa oleifera extract on parasitemia, monocyte activation, and organomegaly in a malaria-infected animal model.
results_summary: The study found that 50% Moringa leaf extract was effective in reducing parasitemia and minimizing liver and spleen enlargement, while 25% extract induced monocyte activation and reduced kidney enlargement.
population_specificity: Male Mus musculus (mice) infected with Plasmodium berghei ANKA.
effective_dosage: 25%, 50%, and 75% concentrations of Moringa leaf extract.
study_duration: 6 days of observation followed by termination on day 7.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how different roasting conditions affect bioactive compounds and antioxidant capacity in moringa seed kernels (MSKs).
results_summary: Light and medium roasting increased glucomoringin (GMG) content and enhanced total phenolic content and antioxidant capacity, while excessive roasting degraded GMG but increased other phenolic acids and alkaloids.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on MSKs)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the anticancer effects of Moringa oleifera extracts on Oral squamous cell carcinoma.
results_summary: The review found that Moringa oleifera components exhibit antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, anticancer, and chemopreventive properties, with all 11 studies showing a low risk of bias. However, more clinical trials are needed to confirm its efficacy and safety as a complementary therapy.
population_specificity: In-vitro investigations, molecular analyses, and animal models (no human subjects specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of a gelatin-chitosan-moringa leaf extract (G-CH-M) biopolymer for biomedical applications, particularly in wound care and contamination prevention.
results_summary: The biopolymer showed high antibacterial activity, especially against S. aureus, effectively protected plasmid DNA from oxidative stress, and exhibited minimal hemolysis (<2% at 50 mg/mL). However, it had no significant effect on E. coli swarming motility.
population_specificity: Bacterial isolates (Gram-positive S. aureus and Gram-negative E. coli) and in vitro models (plasmid DNA protection, hemolysis assay).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of Moringa oleifera leaf polysaccharide (MOLP) on intestinal flora in mice with DSS-induced ulcerative colitis.
results_summary: MOLP-H (100 mg/kg/day) improved intestinal flora diversity and increased beneficial bacteria (Firmicutes) while reducing pathogenic bacteria (Helicobacter) in DSS-induced colitis mice. The treatment restored microbial balance, suggesting MOLP-H may act as a prebiotic.
population_specificity: DSS-induced ulcerative colitis mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize and evaluate bioplastic films using Moringa oleifera gum combined with other materials to improve physicochemical properties for packaging applications.
results_summary: The study found that bioplastic films with higher citric acid content exhibited good elongation, oxygen barrier properties, and biodegradation rates (>95%), while varying glycerol and citric acid amounts allowed tuning of hydrophilicity, hydrophobicity, rigidity, and flexibility.
population_specificity: Not applicable (material science study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety threshold of Moringa homogenate in rats by assessing general behavior, body weight, food intake, blood and serum biochemical indices, and histopathology.
results_summary: The study found that a dose of 6 g/kg BW caused diarrhea and gastrointestinal inflammation in rats, while lower doses (≤3 g/kg BW) showed no adverse effects on weight, food intake, or blood parameters. No abnormal deaths occurred in any group.
population_specificity: Sprague Dawley rats (n=40)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how adding plant-based organic compost to clay soil affects metal content, bioavailability, and nutrient accumulation in Moringa oleifera leaves.
results_summary: The study found that compost addition significantly altered soil metal concentrations and increased nutrient accumulation in Moringa leaves, except for cobalt and chromium. The 30% compost mix yielded the highest nutrient levels, and the harvested leaves were deemed safe for human consumption.
population_specificity: Moringa oleifera plants grown in clay soil amended with plant-based compost.
effective_dosage: Soil amended with 15%, 30%, 45%, and 60% plant-based organic compost by volume.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the neuroprotective and antioxidant effects of Moringa seed extracts (MSE) against chlorpyrifos-induced cerebral and ocular toxicity in mice.
results_summary: MSE normalized pro-inflammatory markers and AChE serum levels, reduced oxidative stress, and increased antioxidant markers in cerebral and ocular tissues, with dose-dependent effects most evident at 100 mg/kg.
population_specificity: Mature male Wistar Albino mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Moringa oleifera seed husk-derived microparticles, alone and in hybrid cryogels, for removing heavy metal ions from laboratory waste.
results_summary: The study found that hybrid cryogels (CMC-MS25 and CMC-MS50) removed over 90% of targeted metal ions, with Cu2+ adsorption facilitated by electrostatic interactions and chelation. The adsorbents were reusable and scalable, suggesting a cost-effective solution for metal recovery.
population_specificity: Laboratory waste with specific heavy metal contaminants (Cr6+, Mn2+, Co2+, Fe3+, Ni2+, Cu2+, Zn2+, Sr2+, Hg2+, Pb2+).
study_duration: Not specified (batch and column adsorption experiments).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the phenotypic and genotypic characteristics of P. aeruginosa and S. aureus and test the efficacy of Moringa oleifera aqueous extract in inhibiting their virulence.
results_summary: Moringa oleifera aqueous extract at 0.312 mg/ml significantly reduced the expression of the P. aeruginosa pslA biofilm gene (fold change 0.40332), indicating potential antimicrobial effects against these pathogens. The extract showed inhibitory effects on biofilm formation and virulence gene expression.
population_specificity: Bacterial isolates (P. aeruginosa and S. aureus) from food sources (raw milk, Kariesh cheese, ice cream, processed cheese).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate Moringa oleifera's potential as a dietary supplement to alleviate heat stress in female rabbits by measuring improvements in hormonal and biochemical responses.
results_summary: Moringa supplementation significantly reduced corticosterone levels (18.39% lower than control), improved triiodothyronine levels, and enhanced estradiol and follicle-stimulating hormone compared to other treatments. It also positively affected glucose, protein, albumin, and globulin levels while reducing cholesterol and creatinine.
population_specificity: Female rabbits under heat stress in South West Nigeria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of whey protein and M. oleifera gel, alone or in combination, on osseointegration in rabbits.
results_summary: The experimental group showed significant differences in osteoblast and osteocyte counts after two weeks, with mature bone development by six weeks compared to the control group's woven bone. Immunohistochemical results indicated early positive expression of osteoblast cells in the experimental group at two weeks.
population_specificity: Six rabbits with titanium implants in their femurs.

study_goal: The abstract does not specify a study goal related to Moringa.
results_summary: The abstract does not report any findings related to Moringa.
population_specificity: The abstract mentions people living with HIV (PLWHIV) but does not specify if Moringa was studied in this population.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Moringa oleifera leaf aqueous extract on energy metabolism and antioxidant function in young male adults.
results_summary: The supplement group showed improved upper- and lower-body strength, treadmill endurance, and favorable changes in blood biochemical parameters (glucose, urea, malondialdehyde, glutathione peroxidase activity) compared to the placebo group.
population_specificity: Young male adults (26.3 ± 3.5 years)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Moringa oleifera leaf supplementation on CD4 counts, viral load, and anthropometric measures in HIV-positive adults on antiretroviral therapy (ART).
results_summary: Moringa supplementation significantly increased CD4 cell counts compared to the placebo group, but no significant differences were observed in viral load or anthropometric parameters (weight and BMI).
population_specificity: HIV-positive adults on ART in Nigeria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a nutritional supplement containing Moringa Oleifera, combined with Tadalafil, on improving erectile function in men with mild to moderate vasculogenic erectile dysfunction.
results_summary: The study found that the combination of Tadalafil and the nutritional supplement (including Moringa) significantly improved IIEF-5 scores compared to Tadalafil alone, suggesting enhanced endothelial function and cGMP production. No hormonal or metabolic differences were observed between groups.
population_specificity: Men aged 38-69 with mild to moderate vasculogenic erectile dysfunction.
effective_dosage: Nutritional supplement (containing Moringa) administered once daily (exact dosage not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Moringa oleifera leaves supplementation on the quality of life (QoL) of HIV-positive adults on antiretroviral therapy (ART).
results_summary: The study found that Moringa supplementation significantly improved physical, psychological, level of independence, and social relationship domains of QoL in HIV-positive adults compared to the control group. The control group showed improvements only in social relationships, environment, and spirituality domains.
population_specificity: HIV-positive adults in Nigeria on ART.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of Moringa oleifera leaf powder supplementation compared to nutritional counseling on the nutritional and immune status of people living with HIV undergoing antiretroviral therapy.
results_summary: Patients receiving Moringa supplementation showed significantly greater increases in BMI and albumin levels compared to the control group receiving nutritional counseling. The study concluded that Moringa supplementation could be an effective local solution to improve nutritional intake and status in this population.
population_specificity: Adult HIV-infected patients in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, stable on antiretroviral therapy (WHO clinical stages 2, 3, or 4).
effective_dosage: Daily Moringa oleifera leaf powder (exact dosage not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the antipathogenic potential, therapeutic properties, and ethnomedicinal uses of Moringa oleifera, particularly for oral health care.
results_summary: The study highlights Moringa's bioactive compounds and ethnomedicinal applications, suggesting its potential in reducing adverse effects of conventional medicines and improving oral health, though specific clinical outcomes are not detailed.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing studies)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding motor imagery (MI) training via telerehabilitation to conventional treatment improves pain, kinesiophobia, and functionality in patients with distal radius fractures (DRF).
results_summary: The study found that MI combined with conventional treatment significantly improved wrist function, extension range of motion, and hand grip strength compared to conventional treatment alone, with notable effect sizes. Both groups showed improvements in pain, muscle strength, and quality of life, but the MI group had superior outcomes in specific functional measures.
population_specificity: Patients aged 18-65 with distal radius fractures treated conservatively.
effective_dosage: MI treatment was administered in addition to traditional rehabilitation (three times a week for 8 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether autistic adults can engage in motor imagery by comparing their performance in executing, perceiving, and imagining hand movements with non-autistic adults.
results_summary: The study found that motor imagery processes are relatively intact in autistic adults, with Fitts' Law relationships observed across execution, imagination, and perception tasks for both groups. Movement times were longest during imagination and shortest during perception, suggesting motor imagery could be explored as a therapy for motor coordination difficulties in autism.
population_specificity: Twenty autistic adults and twenty age- and IQ-matched non-autistic controls.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (behavioral tasks, not a supplement).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of isolated and combined applications of Motor Imagery (MI) and Action Observation (AO), along with Brain-Machine Interfaces (BMI), on upper limb motor changes and cognitive function in Parkinson's disease (PD).
results_summary: The study protocol expects improvements in upper limb motor function (measured by the Test d'Évaluation des Membres Supérieurs de Personnes Âgées and other scales) and cognitive function (assessed via the PD Cognitive Rating Scale), though final results are not yet reported.
population_specificity: Individuals with Parkinson's disease (PD).
study_duration: 10 sessions, with follow-up four weeks post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether motor imagery-enhanced therapy using the Erigo®Pro walking table improves balance and trunk stability in acute stroke patients.
results_summary: Motor imagery-enhanced therapy showed significant improvements in trunk stability and balance, with statistical trends confirming its superiority in frontal plane balance. It also increased transversus abdominis muscle tension.
population_specificity: Sixty-six acute stroke patients with an average age of 64.85 ± 18.62 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining kinesthetic motor imagery-based brain-computer interface (KI-BCI) with transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) is more effective for improving upper limb function in subacute stroke patients than using either intervention alone.
results_summary: KI-BCI showed superior efficacy compared to tDCS alone in improving upper limb motor function and daily living abilities. The combined BCI-tDCS group did not achieve the hypothesized optimal outcome, though tDCS alone reduced quantitative EEG indices, suggesting potential future benefits.
population_specificity: Subacute stroke survivors (n=48)
effective_dosage: KI-BCI group: 30 min/day; tDCS group: 30 min/day; BCI-tDCS group: 15 min tDCS + 15 min KI-BCI/day

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of guided imagery techniques, particularly Motor Imagery (MI), in improving motor recovery in stroke patients.
results_summary: MI showed benefits for gait, balance, and upper limb function in stroke rehabilitation, with enhanced effects when combined with gait training or action observation. However, methodological concerns like allocation concealment and blinding were noted.
population_specificity: Stroke patients (average age 50-70, 35% female)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of neurofeedback (NF) training versus motor imagery (MI) training without feedback in enhancing upper limb motor recovery in chronic stroke survivors.
results_summary: The NF group showed a higher improvement in Fugl-Meyer Assessment Upper Extremity (FMA-UE) scores post-intervention compared to the MI group, with significant improvement only in the NF group. The NF group also exhibited more pronounced lateralisation in EEG laterality index (LI) and maintained improvement at one-month follow-up.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke survivors with partial upper-limb motor impairment (FMA-UE > 21) and partially functional corticospinal tract (CST).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a novel BCI combining action observation, motor imagery, and steady-state motion visual evoked potential (CAMS) could enhance cortical excitability and improve classification performance for motor rehabilitation.
results_summary: The CAMS intervention increased negativity in movement-related cortical potential (MRCP) components, indicating enhanced cortical excitability, and achieved a median classification accuracy of 83.8%. The findings suggest CAMS can effectively engage motor cortex activity and improve BCI performance.
population_specificity: 25 healthy volunteers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining action observation (AO) and motor imagery (MI) improves healthcare students' ability to locate anatomical structures compared to traditional lectures or AO alone.
results_summary: Immediately post-intervention, both AO and AO+MI groups outperformed the control group in accuracy. At one-week follow-up, only the AO+MI group retained significantly higher accuracy compared to AO alone.
population_specificity: Entry-level healthcare students

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether kinesthetic motor imagery (MI) of the concentric or eccentric phase of back squats, performed concomitantly with physical training, could improve force and power in expert athletes.
results_summary: Both MI groups (MICONCENTRIC and MIECCENTRIC) showed significant improvements in 5 RM force and power compared to the control group, with the MIECCENTRIC group outperforming the MICONCENTRIC group in 5 RM workload. However, the MIECCENTRIC group reported higher effort perception and task difficulty.
population_specificity: CrossFit® athletes of national level (n = 100).
effective_dosage: 3 resistance training sessions per week, ~1 hour per week, with MI performed during the back squat exercise.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term impacts and neurobiological mechanisms of Motor Imagery (MI) and Acupuncture Synchronized with MI (ASMI) therapies in stroke rehabilitation.
results_summary: Scale data showed behavioral improvements in both treatment groups. EEG and fNIRS data revealed significant differences in specific frequency bands between the groups, suggesting distinct neurobiological effects of the therapies.
population_specificity: Stroke patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the feasibility and impact of motor imagery practice (MP) of voluntary cough (VC) and expiratory muscle strength training (EMST) on pulmonary and cough function in community-dwelling adults.
results_summary: The study found that MP of VC and EMST was feasible (95% adherence) and improved voluntary cough, with significant increases in peak expiratory flow rate (PEF) from both handheld devices and cough spirometry. Minimal burden was reported, as indicated by low Exercise Therapy Burden Questionnaire scores.
population_specificity: Twenty community-dwelling adults.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and preliminary efficacy of BCI-VR pedaling training on attention, executive function, and lower-extremity function in stroke patients.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in lower-extremity strength, balance, walking stability, attention, and general cognitive function post-intervention, with no adverse events reported. A strong correlation was observed between balance improvements and cognitive test performance.
population_specificity: Twelve stroke patients with motor imagery ability, capable of walking 10 meters continuously.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes per session, 5 days per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the concept, classification, mechanism, application, and effectiveness of motor imagery therapy for upper limb motor function rehabilitation in stroke patients with hemiplegia in China.
results_summary: Motor imagery therapy was found to effectively promote the rehabilitation of upper limb function in stroke patients, with evidence supporting its implementation in medical and rehabilitation institutions. The review summarized available Chinese experience to validate its application.
population_specificity: Stroke patients with hemiplegia in China.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the performance of a wearable motor imagery-based brain-computer interface (MI-BCI) system for online classification of MI-EEG signals, focusing on reducing setup time and enhancing portability for stroke rehabilitation.
results_summary: The wearable MI-BCI system achieved average offline and online accuracies of 85.21% and 76.54%, respectively, and demonstrated comparable performance to a commercial Neuroscan device (77.84% vs. 76.50%). The system showed superior performance with fewer channels and was validated on a large number of subjects.
population_specificity: Sixty-six healthy subjects (46 for offline/online experiments, 20 for comparison experiment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the response to motor imagery interventions using visual or auditory inputs in patients with persistent pelvic pain and assess how mental visualization capacity influences outcomes.
results_summary: Auditory motor imagery showed a nonsignificant reduction in pain intensity, while visual input had no effect. Attention to pain improved in the visual group but remained stable in the auditory group, with mental visualization capacity not significantly impacting outcomes.
population_specificity: Forty patients diagnosed with persistent pelvic pain.
effective_dosage: Six motor imagery sessions over 2 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the relationship between menstrual symptoms and motor imagery skills in young women.
results_summary: The study found weak negative correlations between menstrual symptoms (negative effects/somatic complaints and pain intensity) and motor imagery skills (kinesthetic and visual imagery). Chronic menstrual pain negatively affected both kinesthetic and visual imagery abilities.
population_specificity: 117 women aged 18-40 experiencing menstruation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether gait training combined with motor imagery (MI) has a greater effect on gait in people with Parkinson's disease (PD) compared to gait training alone.
results_summary: The study is still ongoing, but it aims to compare the effects of MI-inclusive gait training (GiG) with standard gait training (GaG) on gait speed, variability, and other functional outcomes in PD patients, with results to be measured post-training and at an 8-week follow-up.
population_specificity: Individuals with idiopathic Parkinson's disease and unimpaired cognition.
study_duration: 6 weeks of intervention with an 8-week follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether motor imagery activates the coagulation system and poses a thrombotic risk.
results_summary: Motor imagery had virtually no effect on coagulation activation but caused significant plasma expansion (7.53% plasma volume change). No significant changes in coagulation parameters were observed.
population_specificity: Ten healthy young subjects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether BCI training with MI-contingent feedback improves upper limb function and neural plasticity more effectively than MI-independent feedback in chronic stroke patients.
results_summary: The MI-contingent feedback BCI group showed significantly greater improvements in wrist extensor muscle strength and active range of motion, along with enhanced functional connectivity in both hemispheres, compared to the MI-independent feedback group.
population_specificity: Persons with chronic stroke

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supplementing motor imagery (MI) training with somatosensory stimulation could enhance MI capabilities in healthy participants.
results_summary: The intervention group showed a significant increase in sensorimotor rhythm event-related desynchronization (SMR-ERD) compared to the control group, indicating improved MI ability due to somatosensory stimulation. The combination of electrical and mechanical stimuli enhanced excitability of the sensorimotor cortex.
population_specificity: Healthy participants (n=16)
effective_dosage: Neuromuscular electrical stimulation above sensory threshold but below motor threshold (St-NMES), along with passive movement stimulation using an exoskeleton (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and potential efficacy of combining motor imagery (MI) and transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) to enhance motor function.
results_summary: The MIActive group showed significant improvements in time-to-completion immediately after the intervention and at one-week follow-up, along with lower ΔO2Hb levels compared to other groups, suggesting MI and tDCS could improve motor function.
population_specificity: Not specified beyond participants in a controlled trial (likely healthy adults, given the context).
effective_dosage: Not specified (only mentions "active or sham tDCS" during MI session).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the medium- and long-term effects of graded motor imagery (GMI) combined with usual care on affective and clinical outcomes in patients with chronic shoulder pain.
results_summary: At 6-month and 1-year follow-ups, GMI showed statistically and clinically significant improvements in pain intensity, fear of movement, catastrophization, shoulder range of motion, and central sensitization. The effects were sustained over time, with notable reductions in pain and functional improvements.
population_specificity: 148 patients with chronic shoulder pain.
study_duration: 6 weeks of intervention, with follow-ups at 6 months and 1 year.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine motor imagery ability and its association with pain, functional status, neck awareness, and depression in individuals with chronic neck pain.
results_summary: Individuals with chronic neck pain showed impaired motor imagery ability, which was weakly to moderately correlated with pain intensity, cervical extensor endurance, neck awareness, and depression levels. Regression analysis indicated that motor imagery ability could explain these factors, suggesting potential benefits for functional and psychosocial outcomes.
population_specificity: 60 individuals with chronic neck pain, aged 18-65 years (83% female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of motor imagery (MI) and action observation (AO) combined with physical exercise on pelvic floor and related structures in healthy women.
results_summary: MI and AO groups showed significant improvements in pelvic floor muscle strength and lumbo-pelvic motor control, with AO showing early improvements at 1 week. Pain sensitivity improved in all groups, with MI showing early changes.
population_specificity: Forty-four healthy women.
effective_dosage: Six sessions at 3 sessions/week for 2 weeks.

study_goal: To explore the effects of telerehabilitation-based motor imagery (Tele-MI) training on motor imagery ability, motor function, and performance in children with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD).
results_summary: Tele-MI training improved motor imagery ability in children with DMD, with large interaction effects observed for visual and kinesthetic imagery scores. Small-to-medium effects were noted on motor function, particularly involving the trunk.
population_specificity: Children with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) and healthy children as controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of graded motor imagery (GMI) versus transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) in improving pain and functionality in patients with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Both GMI and TENS showed significant within-group improvements, but GMI demonstrated superior outcomes in knee flexion ROM, knee extensor muscle strength, WOMAC-pain, WOMAC-function, VAS-activity, knee flexor muscle strength, and WOMAC-stiffness, with results maintained for 6 weeks post-treatment.
population_specificity: Patients with knee osteoarthritis (n=46).
study_duration: 8 weeks of treatment, with a 6-week follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to verify the immediate and sustained effects of action observation and motor imagery (AOMI) using virtual reality (VR) on myo-prostheses control and assess the impact of visual feedback of EMG signals during AOMI.
results_summary: AOMI using VR showed sustained effects on motor learning of myo-prosthetic control, with significant improvements in the Grasp Force Adjustment Test (GFAT) 1 week post-intervention in both VR+ and VR groups compared to controls. Immersion was higher in VR groups, but no significant difference was found between VR+ and VR groups in post-hoc tests.
population_specificity: 24 healthy right-handed individuals wearing a myo-prostheses simulator on their dominant hands.
study_duration: Immediate effects assessed post-intervention and sustained effects evaluated 1 week later.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining motor imagery (MI) with non-invasive brain stimulation (NIBS) is more effective than either intervention alone for improving upper limb motor function and daily living activities after stroke.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that combining MI with NIBS significantly improved upper limb motor function and daily living activities compared to MI or NIBS alone, with strong statistical significance (P < 0.00001). Subgroup analyses indicated that the effectiveness of the combined therapy varied based on stroke stage, MI type, and NIBS type.
population_specificity: Stroke patients (886 participants across 14 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether motor imagery training improves balance, gait parameters, and ataxia severity in children post-medulloblastoma resection compared to traditional physical therapy alone.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in balance, ataxia severity, and gait parameters in both groups, with greater benefits in the motor imagery group (though statistical significance was marginal, P > 0.05). Motor imagery combined with physical therapy was deemed an effective rehabilitation approach.
population_specificity: Children aged 7-9 years with cerebellar ataxia following medulloblastoma resection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Motor Imagery (MI) in improving motor symptoms, balance, gait, and quality of life in Parkinson's disease (PD) patients.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in balance and gait, particularly in the Timed Up and Go (TUG) test with cognitive tasks (85.2% improvement) and walking speed (5.1% improvement). However, results for upper limb function and speech were inconclusive due to study heterogeneity and lack of focus.
population_specificity: Parkinson's disease patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of an online graded motor imagery (GMI) program in reducing pain intensity and improving sexual function in women with genito-pelvic pain/penetration disorder (GPPPD).
results_summary: The online GMI group showed significant reductions in pain intensity and improvements in sexual function. Participants with better movement imagery abilities had greater improvements, while those with negative beliefs about vaginal penetration had lower sexual function scores.
population_specificity: Women diagnosed with genito-pelvic pain/penetration disorder (GPPPD).
effective_dosage: 2-week segments of left/right judgment exercises, mental simulation of movements, and gradual exposure therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the temporal congruence between imagined and executed movements in NSCLBP patients and explore group differences in movement chronometry, psychological well-being, and disability.
results_summary: NSCLBP patients showed significant temporal incongruence in both lumbar flexion and TUG tasks, executing movements more slowly than imagined, while asymptomatic subjects displayed incongruence only in the TUG task. Correlations were found between execution delays, higher disability, and greater fear of movement in NSCLBP patients.
population_specificity: 28 NSCLBP patients and 28 asymptomatic subjects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether individualized cortical responses to rTMS treatments influence the effectiveness of rTMS-induced motor imagery decoding enhancement in stroke patients.
results_summary: Stroke patients with different neural reorganization patterns responded individually to rTMS therapy, with those without cortical lesions showing significant activation increases in the ipsilesional hemisphere and improved motor imagery decoding accuracy when receiving ipsilesional activation therapy. Recovery rates were higher in patients without cortical lesions receiving ipsilesional activation therapy compared to those receiving suppression therapy.
population_specificity: Subacute stroke patients (26 total, divided into four groups).
effective_dosage: Four rTMS treatments: ipsilesional 10 Hz, contralesional 1 Hz, ipsilesional 1 Hz, and sham stimulation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of telerehabilitation-based graded motor imagery (GMI) training on pain and pain-related factors in people with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant reductions in pain intensity (both general and neuropathic), improved motor imagery ability, fatigue, depression, quality of life, and cognitive functions compared to the control group. No significant effects were observed for anxiety, sleep quality, daytime sleepiness, or verbal memory.
population_specificity: People with multiple sclerosis (32 participants, 16 in intervention and 16 in control groups).
effective_dosage: 2 weeks of implicit MI training followed by 6 weeks of explicit MI training (frequency not specified).
study_duration: 8 weeks of intervention with assessments at baseline, week 8 (post-treatment), and week 12 (follow-up).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding neurofeedback to motor imagery (MI) training could further improve grasping ability in people with C6-C7 tetraplegia compared to MI alone or a control condition.
results_summary: The study found that MI training significantly improved tenodesis grasp in people with C6-C7 tetraplegia, and the researchers hypothesized that neurofeedback could further enhance this improvement. The trial design included multiple outcome measures to assess kinematic, strength, dexterity, quality of life, and brain reorganization effects.
population_specificity: Inpatients with C6-C7 tetraplegia (n=21).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect and mechanism of motor imagery based on action observation treatment in improving swallowing function for dysphagia patients with Wallenberg syndrome.
results_summary: The experimental group showed significant improvements in swallowing function scores and extensive activation in multiple brain regions during swallowing motor imagery, suggesting the therapy's effectiveness. The mechanism may involve selective activation of the mirror neuron system.
population_specificity: Thirty in-patient adults with dysphagia due to Wallenberg syndrome.
effective_dosage: Once daily for 14 days (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether integrating dynamic motor imagery (MOTIFS model) into physical rehabilitation improves psychological readiness and physical performance in individuals with traumatic knee injuries.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in psychological readiness (ACL-RSI) or side hop limb symmetry index between the MOTIFS and Care-as-Usual groups. Enjoyment scores also did not meet the continuation criteria, indicating the need for major modifications to the MOTIFS trial.
population_specificity: Individuals undergoing rehabilitation for traumatic knee injuries (n=42).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of adding motor imagery priming prior to task-specific practice on activity and motor impairment outcomes in stroke rehabilitation compared to task-specific practice alone.
results_summary: Motor imagery priming had a very small to large effect on activity and motor impairment outcomes, with standardized mean differences of 0.48 for activity and 0.51 for impairment. The evidence quality was low to moderate.
population_specificity: Adult stroke survivors

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Graded Motor Imagery (GMI) and Mirror Therapy (MT) in reducing pain, improving function, and managing swelling in patients with Complex Regional Pain Syndrome (CRPS).
results_summary: GMI and MT reduced pain by an average of 20 points on the Neuropathic Pain Scale (NPS) and improved function, with GMI also contributing to some reduction in swelling. MT showed significant pain reduction and functional improvements, particularly in post-stroke CRPS patients, though small sample sizes and mixed designs limit generalizability.
population_specificity: Patients with Complex Regional Pain Syndrome (CRPS), including post-stroke CRPS patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare motor imagery ability in chronic rotator cuff-related shoulder pain (C-RCRSP) patients versus pain-free controls and assess its association with central sensitization.
results_summary: C-RCRSP patients had significantly poorer motor imagery abilities compared to pain-free controls (p < 0.001). Those with higher central sensitization (CSI≥40) showed even worse motor imagery performance, slower response times, and greater pain-related impairments.
population_specificity: Chronic rotator cuff-related shoulder pain (C-RCRSP) patients (n=48) and pain-free controls (n=45).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Graded Motor Imagery (GMI) on Quality of Life, pain, kinesiophobia, pain catastrophization, and anxiety in participants with Painful Diabetic Neuropathy (PDN).
results_summary: The study concluded that this high-quality RCT would provide important information on GMI's efficacy for improving QoL, pain levels, and associated psychological factors, aligning with the biopsychosocial model of pain.
population_specificity: Participants aged 18-75 with Type 1 or Type 2 diabetes and a DN-4 score ≥3.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding graded motor imagery to a multimodal physical therapy program improves outcomes (SPADI scores, pain with activities, Q-DASH scores, and ROM) in patients with frozen shoulder compared to multimodal physical therapy alone.
results_summary: Graded motor imagery combined with multimodal physiotherapy showed clinically superior improvements in SPADI and Q-DASH scores but not in activity-related pain or ROM. The benefits were statistically significant but some differences did not meet the prespecified MCID.
population_specificity: 38 patients with clinically and radiologically confirmed primary frozen shoulder, with ROM limitations compared to the unaffected shoulder.
effective_dosage: 12 sessions, each ~45 minutes, twice a week for 6 weeks.
study_duration: 6 weeks of intervention, with assessments at baseline, 6 weeks, and 8 weeks.

study_goal: To investigate the effectiveness of motor imagery (MI) in isolation or combined with action observation (AO) compared to sham interventions for improving freezing of gait, speed, physical function, and balance in individuals with Parkinson's Disease.
results_summary: MI showed statistically significant improvements in speed and balance at post-treatment compared to sham interventions. The evidence was of very low certainty, suggesting modest but notable effects.
population_specificity: Individuals with Parkinson's Disease

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of BCI-based rehabilitation on lower limb motor dysfunction in acute ischemic stroke patients by evaluating motor function, walking ability, and daily living activities.
results_summary: The study found that combining conventional rehabilitation with BCI rehabilitation significantly improved lower limb motor function, walking ability, and daily living activities compared to conventional rehabilitation alone, with statistically significant improvements in FMA-LE, FAC, and MBI scores.
population_specificity: 64 patients with acute ischemic stroke experiencing lower limb motor dysfunction.
effective_dosage: BCI rehabilitation was administered for 1 hour daily (30 minutes in the morning and 30 minutes in the afternoon), alongside conventional rehabilitation (70 minutes daily).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how acute stress influences motor imagery (MI) capacity and temporal congruence (TC) in young, healthy subjects unfamiliar with MI.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in MI capacity or TC between the stress and control groups, suggesting acute stress does not significantly affect MI performance in this population. MI may remain a useful technique even in stressful situations.
population_specificity: 62 young, healthy subjects (mean age 20.65; 39 females, 23 males) unfamiliar with MI.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of a combined program of task-oriented work and motor imagery on improving motor competence in children susceptible to Developmental Coordination Disorder (DCD).
results_summary: The study protocol suggests that motor imagery, combined with task-oriented work, shows promise in addressing motor competence issues in children with DCD, though specific efficacy results are not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Children aged 6 to 12 years old susceptible to DCD.
study_duration: Not explicitly stated, but implied by the 20-session intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Motor Imagery (MI) on upper- and lower-extremity function and functional performance in patients with stroke.
results_summary: More than half of the upper-extremity function studies reported improved performance in various assessments, while six of 15 high-quality studies on upper extremity and six of 14 studies on gait and balance reported significant effects. MI training and conventional rehabilitation programs were found to effectively enhance upper limb functional abilities, gait speed, and balance in acute and chronic stroke patients.
population_specificity: Patients with stroke (acute and chronic stages)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects of Motor Imagery on static and dynamic balance and fear of re-injury in professional football players with Grade II ankle sprains.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant improvements in static balance for the right lower extremity and heart rate in the Motor Imagery group compared to the placebo group. Both groups showed significant results before and after the intervention, but the Motor Imagery group demonstrated superior outcomes in specific measures.
population_specificity: Professional football players with Grade II ankle sprains.
effective_dosage: Six intervention sessions (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the influence of action observation (AO) perspective (egocentric vs. allocentric) on the effectiveness of combined action observation and motor imagery (AOMI) training for novice learning of a complex judo throw.
results_summary: AOMI training improved motor skill performance, with allocentric perspective (AOMIALLO) reducing specific errors more than egocentric (AOMIEGO). Self-efficacy increased across all conditions, and both AOMI conditions enhanced mental representation structures compared to control.
population_specificity: Thirty novice participants learning the Osoto Gari judo throw.
study_duration: 7 days (pre-test, acquisition Days 2-6, post-test Day 7, retention-test Day 14)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of combining motor imagery with action observation on athletes' performance and performance perception.
results_summary: The study found no significant improvement in physical performance after the intervention, but the experimental group showed enhanced performance estimation following video observation, not motor imagery. The control group did not exhibit this improvement.
population_specificity: 21 voluntary participants (10 male athletes).
effective_dosage: 24-minute motor imagery sessions during video observation, three times weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the acute effects of motor imagery-based physical activity on maternal well-being and physiological parameters in women with high-risk pregnancies.
results_summary: The study found that motor imagery-based physical activity significantly improved maternal well-being and oxygen saturation without adverse effects on the fetus or uterine contractions. The intervention showed a significant main effect of time on maternal heart rate and well-being, with a notable group-by-time interaction for maternal well-being.
population_specificity: Women with high-risk pregnancies.
effective_dosage: Not specified (diaphragmatic-breathing exercise and motor imagery-based physical activity).
study_duration: From August 2023 to January 2024 (exact intervention duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of motor imagery (MI) training, both alone and combined with low-frequency sound (LFS), on force torque production and neural mechanisms during maximal voluntary contractions of the quadriceps.
results_summary: The study found that both MI and MI + LFS groups showed increased force torque between Posttest and Retention, while the control group experienced a decline. Regression analyses indicated a negative relationship between force performance and EEG activity in the MI + LFS group, suggesting transient interference of LFS on cortical activity.
population_specificity: 60 participants (20 per group: MI, MI + LFS, control) undergoing maximal voluntary contractions of the quadriceps.
effective_dosage: Not specified (single session of MI or MI + LFS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential impact of combining action observation, motor imagery, and peripheral nerve stimulation on hand dexterity in stroke patients.
results_summary: The study found preliminary evidence of an immediate improvement in hand dexterity, thumb-index pinch force, and thumb tapping speed after a single session of the combined intervention. The results suggest a possible benefit, but further research is needed to confirm these findings.
population_specificity: 10 subacute stroke patients with motor impairment.
effective_dosage: 10-minute session with concurrent action observation, motor imagery, and electrical wrist stimulation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the therapeutic potential of a non-invasive neuromodulation protocol combining tDCS and AO+MI for improving motor, cognitive, and functional outcomes in a patient with corticobasal degeneration.
results_summary: The study found improvements in balance, functional strength, and long-term cognitive functions (attentional set-shifting, inhibitory control, verbal attentional span, and working memory), but no change in walking speed. Emotional well-being and general health improved post-treatment but were not sustained, while falls efficacy showed long-term improvement.
population_specificity: A 70-year-old female patient diagnosed with probable corticobasal degeneration (CBD).
effective_dosage: 20 sessions of anodal tDCS (2 mA for 20 minutes) combined with AO+MI (lower limb movements, video observation, and gradual execution).

study_goal: To evaluate the impact of a short-term neuromuscular electrical stimulation program on exercise tolerance and inotropic support necessity in hospitalized patients with advanced heart failure.
results_summary: The neuromuscular electrical stimulation group showed a significantly higher 6-minute walk test distance and a greater reduction in dobutamine dose compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Hospitalized patients with advanced heart failure under continuous intravenous inotropic support.
effective_dosage: Daily training sessions to both lower extremities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of unilateral strength training using neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) versus voluntary contractions on muscle strength and contralateral limb postural control.
results_summary: Both NMES and voluntary contractions similarly increased muscle strength in the trained and contralateral limbs, but neither improved monopedal postural control. No changes were observed in the control group.
population_specificity: 36 non-active healthy male subjects
effective_dosage: 43 contractions of the quadriceps femoris at 20% of MVC, 3 sessions per week

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) could preserve quadriceps muscle mass in patients with acute moderate or severe stroke.
results_summary: NMES significantly reduced the degree of quadriceps muscle thickness loss on both paretic and non-paretic sides compared to the control group, suggesting it may help preserve muscle mass in stroke patients.
population_specificity: Twenty patients with acute, moderate, or severe stroke (average age 68±11 years).
effective_dosage: NMES treatment for bilateral quadriceps muscles (specific parameters not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) on muscle strength, architecture, functional capacity, and endothelial function in patients with chronic kidney failure on hemodialysis.
results_summary: NMES increased lower limb muscle strength and had a protective effect against muscle atrophy in patients with chronic kidney failure on hemodialysis, but no significant changes were observed in functional capacity or endothelial function.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic kidney failure on hemodialysis (n=21).
effective_dosage: 3 times/week (20-34 min per session) during hemodialysis sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of combining blood flow restriction (BFR) with low-intensity neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) on skeletal muscle adaptation, compared to their isolated use or no treatment.
results_summary: The combination of BFR and NMES significantly increased leg strength compared to the control group, while isolated NMES or BFR showed non-significant improvements. No significant changes in muscle size were observed across any group.
population_specificity: Twenty recreationally active subjects.
effective_dosage: Each leg was stimulated for 32 minutes, 4 days per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if daily neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) combined with protein supplementation could protect muscle mass and function in healthy older adults after 5 days of bed rest.
results_summary: NMES+PRO maintained thigh lean mass but did not prevent loss of muscle function. The preservation of muscle mass was linked to reduced expression of atrophy-related genes (myostatin and MAFbx) rather than restored nutrient-induced mTORC1 signaling.
population_specificity: Healthy older adults (~70 years)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the acute effects of patellar tendon vibration combined with wide-pulse width NMES on muscle force, fatigue resistance, and post-exercise recovery in knee extensor muscles.
results_summary: Tendon vibration combined with NMES increased torque-time integral in half of the subjects and reduced voluntary force loss (fatigue) across all participants, but did not affect indirect markers of muscle damage. Negative responders to vibration showed better results with NMES alone.
population_specificity: 16 healthy adults
effective_dosage: NMES at 30 Hz with 1000 μs pulse width; tendon vibration applied in separate sessions
study_duration: Acute effects measured immediately after, 1 h, and 48 h post-intervention

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of the geko™ neuromuscular electrical stimulation device as an adjunctive therapy for non-healing venous leg ulcers and determine its suitability for inclusion in the medical supply formulary.
results_summary: The study found that the geko™ device led to an average weekly reduction in ulcer surface area of 4.5% overall, with adherent patients showing a 7.0% reduction compared to 1.8% in non-adherent patients. Success appeared dependent on adequate arterial status, infection management, and treatment adherence.
population_specificity: Patients with non-healing venous leg ulcers who had failed to heal within 24 weeks of standard therapy (n=11).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a multimodal intervention including neuromuscular electrical stimulation (EStim) could improve mood and cognitive function in adults with progressive multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: Greater participation in the intervention, including EStim, was associated with improvements in anxiety, depression, cognitive function, and executive function over 12 months. Mood and cognitive improvements were more strongly linked to dietary changes than to exercise or stress management.
population_specificity: Adults with progressive multiple sclerosis (MS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of neuromuscular electrical stimulation combined with resistance training and testosterone replacement therapy on body composition and metabolic profile in individuals with spinal cord injury.
results_summary: The study investigated the impact of 16 weeks of neuromuscular electrical stimulation-based resistance training combined with testosterone replacement therapy, but specific results regarding its effects were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic, motor complete spinal cord injury aged 18-50 years.
effective_dosage: Not specified for neuromuscular electrical stimulation; testosterone replacement therapy was administered via transdermal patches (4-6 mg/day).
study_duration: 16 weeks of intervention, with some participants completing an additional 16 weeks of detraining.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of combining neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) with low-frequency repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) on upper extremity motor function in acute/subacute ischemic stroke patients.
results_summary: The study found that NMES combined with rTMS led to the highest percent improvement in motor function (48-99.3%) compared to the control group (13.1-28.1%). Hand motor recovery was significant in both experimental groups but unchanged in the control group, with some motor cortex excitability changes observed via fMRI.
population_specificity: Acute/subacute ischemic stroke patients (n=25).

study_goal: To investigate whether combining mirror therapy with neuromuscular electrical stimulation improves motor recovery and walking ability in stroke patients with foot drop.
results_summary: The combination therapy improved walking ability (10-meter walk test) and reduced spasticity more effectively than mirror therapy alone or control. No significant difference in spasticity was found between the two intervention groups, but the combination group showed greater improvement compared to the control.
population_specificity: Sixty-nine stroke patients with foot drop.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) combined with individualized rehabilitation on muscle strength in ICU survivors.
results_summary: NMES and personalized physiotherapy did not significantly improve muscle strength or functional status at hospital discharge, but showed potential benefits in patients with ICU-acquired weakness at two weeks post-ICU discharge.
population_specificity: 128 ICU survivors (average age 53±16 years).
effective_dosage: Daily NMES sessions (specific parameters not detailed).
study_duration: Duration not explicitly stated, but outcomes were assessed at hospital discharge and up to two weeks post-ICU discharge.

study_goal: To examine the effectiveness of neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) for managing shoulder subluxation after stroke, comparing short and long daily treatment durations.
results_summary: NMES showed a significant treatment effect for reducing shoulder subluxation in acute and subacute stroke patients, regardless of treatment duration, but no significant effect for chronic stroke patients or on arm function and shoulder pain.
population_specificity: Patients with shoulder subluxation post-stroke (acute, subacute, and chronic phases).
effective_dosage: Short (1 hour or less) or long (more than one hour) daily treatment durations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of stimulation intensity change speed (SICS) in Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) on cortical excitability and motor performance.
results_summary: The study found that fast SICS evoked more significant cortical excitability than slow SICS, as measured by EEG analysis, suggesting potential for enhanced motor dysfunction rehabilitation. Brain function areas were sensitive to SICS, indicating NMES's role in improving neural recovery.
population_specificity: Individuals with motor dysfunction (e.g., stroke, spinal cord injury).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential role of neuromuscular electrical stimulation as an intervention for peripheral muscle dysfunction in cystic fibrosis patients.
results_summary: The study suggests neuromuscular electrical stimulation may be beneficial for some cystic fibrosis patients, alongside exercise training and other interventions, but further investigations are needed to confirm its efficacy.
population_specificity: Patients with cystic fibrosis, particularly those with mild-to-moderate phenotypes and severe cases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of neuromuscular electrical stimulation combined with conventional physical therapy versus conventional therapy alone on muscle thickness in critically ill patients.
results_summary: The intervention group maintained rectus abdominis and chest muscle thickness, while the conventional group showed significant reductions. The intervention group also had a shorter ICU stay.
population_specificity: Critically ill patients on mechanical ventilation for 24-48 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if neuromuscular electrical stimulation combined with lupin protein supplementation could reduce muscle volume and strength loss in the calf during prolonged unloading via an orthotic device.
results_summary: The countermeasure significantly reduced muscle volume loss in the triceps surae (-3.5% vs. -11.9% in controls) and mitigated strength decline in specific plantar flexion tests (-9.7% vs. -22.3% in controls). The intervention showed measurable but context-dependent efficacy.
population_specificity: 13 healthy male subjects (age 26.4 ± 3.7 years).
effective_dosage: 20 min of neuromuscular electrical stimulation twice daily + 19 g lupin protein supplementation.

study_goal: To evaluate the effects of high and low frequency/intensity neuromuscular electrical stimulation on physical function and inflammation markers in chronic kidney disease patients during hemodialysis.
results_summary: High frequency/intensity stimulation significantly increased peripheral muscle strength, while both groups improved exercise capacity. Specific inflammatory and muscle trophism marker changes were observed depending on the stimulation strategy.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic kidney disease undergoing hemodialysis (N=51).
effective_dosage: High frequency (50Hz, 72.90mA) and low frequency (5Hz, 13.85mA), 3 times per week for 1 hour.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) is effective for improving quadricep strength and exercise capacity in patients with moderate-to-severe COPD.
results_summary: NMES significantly improved quadricep strength and exercise capacity in moderate-to-severe COPD patients, with standardized mean differences indicating clinically meaningful effects. The study did not find conclusive evidence for improvements in health-related quality of life.
population_specificity: Patients with moderate-to-severe COPD who were unable or unwilling to undertake physical training.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a home-based NMES rehabilitation program plus traditional military amputee rehabilitation (TMARP) versus TMARP alone on quadriceps muscle strength, functional mobility, and pain in military service members with combat-related transtibial amputations.
results_summary: The NMES plus TMARP group showed greater quadriceps strength improvement at 3 weeks (pre-prosthesis) compared to TMARP alone, but no difference was observed post-prosthesis (6-12 weeks). Both groups improved in strength, pain, and functional mobility, with no significant differences between them by study completion.
population_specificity: Military service members aged 19-46 with unilateral transtibial amputations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a footplate NMES device (REVITIVE) on venous flow parameters, limb oedema, and quality of life in patients with chronic venous disease (CVD).
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in venous flow parameters and prevention of limb oedema in the NMES group compared to sham, along with a positive impact on quality of life.
population_specificity: Patients with Clinical Etiological Anatomical and Pathophysiological (CEAP) clinical class C2-C4 venous disease (n=22, mean age 62, BMI 28.6, 15:7 female preponderance).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) on vocal functions in patients with nasopharyngeal carcinoma following radiation therapy.
results_summary: The NMES group showed no significant changes to vocal functions, while the traditional exercise group experienced short-term deterioration at 6 months. Both groups returned to baseline vocal function levels by 12 months.
population_specificity: Newly treated nasopharyngeal carcinoma patients post-radiation therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of NMES versus placebo in reducing pain and opiate use during weightbearing exercises after total hip replacement, and assess its effects on function, hospital stay, and disposition planning.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference between NMES and placebo groups in pain reduction, opiate use, hospital length of stay, or functional outcomes post-THR.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent elective total hip replacement from an outpatient orthopedic service.
effective_dosage: Different intensity levels of stimulation (specific amounts not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Hybrid Assistive Neuromuscular Dynamic Stimulation (HANDS) therapy in improving upper extremity motor function and reducing spasticity in stroke patients.
results_summary: HANDS therapy improved paretic upper extremity motor function after 3 weeks, likely due to disinhibition of the affected hemisphere and modulation of reciprocal inhibition. The therapy facilitated increased use of the paretic hand in daily activities.
population_specificity: Stroke patients with paretic upper extremities.
effective_dosage: Stimulation applied for 8 hours daily, adjusted based on voluntary EMG amplitudes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) on quadriceps muscle strength in adults with advanced disease, as well as its safety, acceptability, and impact on muscle function, exercise capacity, and quality of life.
results_summary: NMES significantly improved quadriceps muscle strength (SMD 0.53) and increased muscle mass, with notable improvements in the 6-minute walk test (35 m increase). However, effects on other exercise tests were inconsistent, and no serious adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Adults with advanced chronic respiratory disease, chronic heart failure, cancer, or HIV/AIDS.

study_goal: To determine if postoperative NMES reduces muscle protein degradation and muscle weakness in cardiovascular surgery patients.
results_summary: NMES led to earlier peak in urinary 3-MH/Cre and significantly greater knee extensor and handgrip strength at POD 7 compared to the non-NMES group.
population_specificity: Patients recovering from cardiovascular surgery.
effective_dosage: Daily NMES from postoperative days 1 to 5.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of neuromuscular electrical stimulation on pulmonary function and functional capacity in patients with chronic kidney disease undergoing hemodialysis.
results_summary: The treatment group showed significant improvements in maximum inspiratory and expiratory pressures, muscular strength, distance covered in the six-minute walk test, and reductions in systolic blood pressure and respiratory frequency compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Adult patients with chronic kidney disease on hemodialysis (n=40, split into control and treatment groups).
effective_dosage: Bilateral femoral quadriceps muscles electrical stimulation for 30 minutes during hemodialysis, three times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether preoperative physiotherapy, including neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES), improves postoperative outcomes in older adults undergoing total knee arthroplasty.
results_summary: The study found minimal evidence supporting the efficacy of preoperative physiotherapy, including NMES, compared to no physiotherapy or usual care. Methodological quality issues were noted in the RCTs evaluating NMES.
population_specificity: Older adults (≥60 years) in the UK undergoing total knee arthroplasty.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy of Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) in preventing and managing venous disease compared to existing treatments.
results_summary: NMES devices improve venous hemodynamic parameters and are non-inferior to intermittent pneumatic compression. They are effective in preventing venous thromboembolism but inferior to low molecular weight heparin, and can reduce symptoms of chronic venous disease.
population_specificity: Patients with venous disease (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) on muscle strength, functional capacity, and body composition in haemodialysis (HD) patients.
results_summary: NMES improved muscle strength, functional capacity, and quadriceps muscle composition in HD patients, suggesting it could help prevent muscle atrophy and physical deterioration. No significant improvements were observed in the control group.
population_specificity: Haemodialysis patients (mean age 67.7 years, 55% male, average 30.3 months on HD).
effective_dosage: Not specified (device: Compex® Theta 500i, applied to quadriceps during dialysis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of contralaterally controlled functional electrical stimulation (CCFES) versus cyclic neuromuscular electrical stimulation (cNMES) for upper limb rehabilitation in chronic stroke patients.
results_summary: CCFES showed greater improvement in hand dexterity (measured by the Box and Block Test) compared to cNMES at 6 months post-treatment, particularly in patients <2 years post-stroke with moderate hand impairment. No significant differences were found in upper extremity Fugl-Meyer or Arm Motor Abilities Test scores between the groups.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke patients (>6 months post-stroke) with moderate to severe upper extremity hemiparesis (n=80).
effective_dosage: 10 sessions/week of CCFES or cNMES-assisted hand opening exercise at home plus 20 sessions of functional task practice in the laboratory.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) and Kinesio Taping (KT) when added to neurodevelopmental therapy (NDT) on posture and sitting in children.
results_summary: NMES showed significant improvement in Gross Motor Function Measure (GMFM) and kyphosis levels compared to the control group, with better results than KT. All groups improved, but NMES was more effective.
