population_specificity: Seventy-five children with posture and sitting impairments.
effective_dosage: Not specified (frequency: applied alongside NDT 4 times a week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and effectiveness of home-based pulmonary rehabilitation, including NMES, on exercise tolerance, anxiety/depression, and HRQoL in COPD patients.
results_summary: NMES significantly improved functional mobility, exercise capacity, depression, and overall HRQoL in COPD patients, with no significant differences observed between NMES and usual endurance exercise groups.
population_specificity: Patients with COPD, including those with severe exercise intolerance.
effective_dosage: NMES was applied for 30 minutes twice a day, every day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate organizational characteristics enabling early mobilization practices, including neuromuscular electrical stimulation, in ICUs across multiple countries.
results_summary: Neuromuscular electrical stimulation was rarely cited as part of early mobilization practices, and its efficacy or outcomes were not specifically analyzed in the study. The focus was on broader ICU practices and staffing factors influencing early mobilization.
population_specificity: Mechanically ventilated patients in ICUs across France, Germany, the United Kingdom, and the United States.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether adding neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) to standard swallow therapy improves dysphagia in stroke patients.
results_summary: NMES, combined with sham inspiratory/expiratory muscle training, improved swallowing security signs at the end of the intervention, but the effect did not persist at the 3-month follow-up. No differences in respiratory complications or Penetration-Aspiration Scale scores were detected between treatment groups and controls.
population_specificity: Sixty-two stroke patients with dysphagia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effectiveness of neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) as part of early mobilization strategies in ICU patients to prevent polyneuromyopathy and improve outcomes.
results_summary: The study found mixed results for NMES, with some trials and a meta-analysis showing no positive effects, but suggested that specific populations, such as patients with weakness due to immobility and preserved neuromuscular excitability, may benefit more.
population_specificity: ICU patients, particularly those with weakness due to immobility and preserved neuromuscular excitability.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of cyclic NMES, EMG-triggered NMES, and sensory stimulation on motor impairment and activity limitations in hemiplegic stroke survivors.
results_summary: All three groups showed significant improvements in motor impairment and functional limitations, with no significant differences between the types of electrical stimulation. The improvements were likely due to spontaneous recovery rather than the specific stimulation method.
population_specificity: Nonhospitalized hemiplegic stroke survivors within 6 months of stroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combined traditional swallow therapy (TST) and neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) therapy could restore TGF-β1/MyoD homeostasis in cervical muscles and mitigate radiation-induced muscle fibrosis in head and neck cancer patients.
results_summary: The study found that NMES combined with TST helped restore TGF-β1 levels to those resembling non-irradiated tissue, suggesting a potential role in preventing or treating radiation-induced muscle fibrosis and dysphagia. Group II (TST/NMES) showed better TGF-β1/MyoD homeostasis compared to Group I (RT alone).
population_specificity: 20 advanced-stage head and neck cancer patients receiving post-operative radiation therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of intravaginal NMES and TTNS combined with PFMT in improving LUTS and quality of life in women with MS.
results_summary: All groups showed improvements in LUTS and PFM function, but the combination of PFMT and intravaginal NMES provided greater benefits in PFM tone, flexibility, and overactive bladder symptoms compared to PFMT alone or with TTNS.
population_specificity: Women with multiple sclerosis (MS) and lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the role and evidence for Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) in post-TKA rehabilitation, focusing on its efficacy and practicality.
results_summary: The study highlighted NMES as one of the rehabilitative modalities that may aid in recovery of strength and range-of-motion after TKA, particularly when incorporated early in the rehabilitation process. However, specific efficacy data or comparative outcomes for NMES were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Patients recovering from total knee arthroplasty (TKA), with specific mention of active and obese subsets.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of effortful swallowing combined with neuromuscular electrical stimulation on hyoid bone movement and swallowing function in stroke patients with dysphagia.
results_summary: The experimental group showed significant increases in anterior and superior hyoid bone movement and improved pharyngeal phase swallowing function compared to the placebo group. The intervention was deemed a novel remedial approach for dysphagic stroke patients.
population_specificity: Fifty stroke patients with mild dysphagia who could swallow against resistance and actively cooperate in training.
effective_dosage: 30 min per session, 5 sessions per week (NMES intensity increased gradually until participants felt a grabbing sensation in the neck).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to update scientific knowledge on the safety of NMES for increasing exercise capacity and preventing cardiac cachexia in patients with implantable cardioverter defibrillators (ICDs).
results_summary: NMES did not show electromagnetic interference (EMI) with ICD function in thigh muscle applications, but EMI was reported in a case involving abdominal muscle stimulation. NMES may be safe for ICD patients if specific precautions are followed.
population_specificity: Patients with implantable cardioverter defibrillators (ICDs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES)-induced blood flow could enhance performance recovery between bouts of high-intensity exercise compared to other recovery interventions.
results_summary: NMES significantly increased calf arterial inflow during recovery, correlating with improved mean and peak power output in subsequent exercise bouts, unlike other interventions. No recovery effects were linked to heart rate or blood lactate levels.
population_specificity: Thirty-three high-intensity intermittent-trained athletes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining Mirror Therapy (MT) with Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) improves muscle strength, balance, motor function, and gait ability in hemiplegic stroke survivors.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in muscle strength, balance (BBS), and gait ability (6mWT) in the experimental group receiving MT combined with NMES compared to the control group. The improvements were statistically significant (P<0.05), particularly in muscle strength and balance.
population_specificity: Hemiplegic stroke survivors (n=27) from a rehabilitation center.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the outcomes of neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) for improving quadriceps muscle strength and function in patients with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: NMES improved quadriceps and hamstring muscle strength and some functional metrics, but showed minimal effects on quality of life and patient-reported outcomes, with mixed results in pain relief and functional scores.
population_specificity: Patients with knee osteoarthritis experiencing quadriceps muscle weakness and decreased function.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of neuromuscular electrical stimulation during weight-bearing exercises on shoulder function and bone mineral density in children with obstetric brachial plexus injury.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in shoulder function and bone mineral density within both groups, with greater improvements observed in the group receiving neuromuscular electrical stimulation compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Children aged 3-5 years with obstetric brachial plexus injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) could be safely applied to heart failure patients with implantable cardioverter defibrillators (ICDs).
results_summary: The study found that NMES could be conducted safely in ICD patients without electromagnetic interference, provided common stimulation methods were used with sufficient monitoring.
population_specificity: Advanced heart failure patients with implantable cardioverter defibrillators (ICDs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the role of skeletal muscles in rehabilitation and evaluate countermeasures, including neuromuscular electrical stimulation, to address muscle wasting.
results_summary: The abstract suggests neuromuscular electrical stimulation is one of several methods to slow or reverse muscle wasting, alongside strength training and other interventions, but does not provide specific efficacy data.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on ageing and chronic disease-related muscle wasting).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) on pain reduction in patients with osteoarthritis (OA) of the knee compared to other non-operative treatments.
results_summary: NMES showed a significant reduction in pain, with a standardized mean difference (SMD) of 1.924, similar to TENS. The study concluded that NMES is effective for pain management in knee OA.
population_specificity: Patients with osteoarthritis (OA) of the knee.
study_duration: Follow-up periods were less than six months in most studies.

study_goal: To assess the feasibility of a trial evaluating trunk muscle training augmented with neuromuscular electrical stimulation (TMT+NMES) for rehabilitating older adults with chronic low back pain and to preliminarily compare its effects on physical function and pain against a passive control intervention.
results_summary: The study found that TMT+NMES led to clinically important improvements in both performance-based and self-reported measures of function, with a 17.2% greater improvement in global functional rating compared to the passive control group. Both groups showed similar pain reduction, but only TMT+NMES significantly enhanced physical function.
population_specificity: Older adults aged 60-85 years with chronic low back pain.
study_duration: Outcomes assessed at 3 and 6 months post-randomization.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) prevents loss of muscle layer thickness and strength in critically ill patients after cardiothoracic surgery and observed changes from preoperative day to hospital discharge.
results_summary: NMES had no significant effect on muscle layer thickness but was associated with a 4.5 times faster regain of muscle strength compared to the control group. Patients regained preoperative muscle strength by discharge but not muscle layer thickness or functional mobility.
population_specificity: Critically ill patients after cardiothoracic surgery, stratified by SAPS II score.
effective_dosage: Not specified (electrical stimulation applied bilaterally to quadriceps muscles).
study_duration: From the first postoperative day until ICU discharge, up to 14 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of home-based neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) as an exercise therapy for improving functional exercise capacity in patients with severe COPD.
results_summary: NMES significantly improved 6-minute walk test distance compared to placebo, with a mean difference of 35.7 meters at 6 weeks. The effect waned after stopping the intervention, and adverse events were similar between groups, with minor skin irritation reported in two participants.
population_specificity: Adults with severe COPD (FEV1 <50% predicted) and incapacitating breathlessness (MRC dyspnoea scale ≥4).
effective_dosage: Daily NMES (specific intensity/frequency not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of NMES targeting sensory input versus motor muscle, combined with traditional swallowing therapy, in improving dysphagia and quality of life in patients with medullary infarction.
results_summary: The sensory approach combined with traditional therapy showed significantly greater improvement in swallowing function and quality of life compared to the motor approach and traditional therapy alone, with the motor approach also outperforming traditional therapy alone.
population_specificity: Patients with dysphagia due to medullary infarction (N=82).
effective_dosage: 20-minute sessions, twice a day, 5 days per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine optimal NMES parameters for maximizing torque production while minimizing discomfort, fatigue, and muscle damage.
results_summary: The study found that pulse duration of 400–600 μs and frequency of 30–50 Hz optimize torque output while reducing discomfort and fatigue. Electrode placement, conditioning programs, and stimulus modulation may further enhance results.
population_specificity: Patients recovering from injury or surgery, particularly targeting the quadriceps muscle.
effective_dosage: Pulse duration 400–600 μs, frequency 30–50 Hz (specific amplitude not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of neuromuscular electrical stimulation as part of a comprehensive rehabilitation program for patients with left-sided heart disease and pulmonary hypertension.
results_summary: The study suggests neuromuscular electrical stimulation is recognized as an important component of rehabilitation, improving muscle strength and endurance, which enhances functional capacity in patients with heart failure. However, specific effects on the LSHD-PH phenotype were not explored.
population_specificity: Patients with left-sided heart disease (HFpEF and HFrEF) and concomitant pulmonary hypertension.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the knee extensor muscle torque production elicited by 2500-Hz burst-modulated alternating current (BMAC) and monophasic pulsed current (MPC) at maximum tolerated stimulation intensity.
results_summary: The study found that MPC produced significantly higher torque (49.5% of maximum volitional isometric contraction) compared to BMAC (29.8%), with statistical significance (P = .002). Treatment order and limb had no effect on torque production.
population_specificity: 20 adults with no history of knee injury.
effective_dosage: Stimulation intensity was incrementally increased to maximum tolerance.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review therapeutic and neuroprosthetic applications of Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) for upper and lower extremity stroke rehabilitation, summarizing efficacy studies and mechanisms of action.
results_summary: The study describes NMES modalities for limb rehabilitation and summarizes evidence supporting peripheral and central mechanisms of action, indicating its potential efficacy in stroke recovery.
population_specificity: Stroke patients requiring upper and lower extremity rehabilitation.

study_goal: To determine if daily NMES applied to ankle dorsiflexors during gait improves muscle volume and strength in children with unilateral spastic cerebral palsy.
results_summary: NMES significantly increased muscle volumes and dorsiflexion strength at week 8 compared to baseline and controls, with some carryover effects (lateral gastrocnemius volume) at week 14. No improvements were seen in lower limb selective motor control.
population_specificity: 32 children (5y 5mo–18y 1mo) with unilateral spastic CP (GMFCS levels I–II).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of contralaterally controlled functional electrical stimulation (CCFES) versus neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) on upper extremity functions in stroke patients.
results_summary: Both CCFES and NMES groups showed significant improvements in upper extremity function, but the CCFES group demonstrated significantly higher scores in Fugl-Meyer assessment, functional test for the hemiplegic upper extremity, and active range of motion of wrist extension compared to the NMES group.
population_specificity: Sixty patients with stroke.
effective_dosage: Biphasic wave with a pulse duration of 200 μs and a frequency of 60 Hz, 20 min per session, 5 sessions per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of neuromuscular electrical stimulation on patients who underwent total knee arthroplasty.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant difference in knee function, pain, or range of motion over a 12-month follow-up. Neuromuscular electrical stimulation was less effective than traditional rehabilitation for function, muscular strength, and range of motion but useful for quadriceps activation in the first days post-surgery.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent total knee arthroplasty.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) with robot-assisted therapy (RT) improves functional outcomes in chronic stroke patients compared to RT alone.
results_summary: The RT + NMES group showed greater improvements in wrist flexor spasticity, movement quality, and hand function compared to the sham group, though both groups improved in other measures without significant differences.
population_specificity: Thirty-nine individuals with chronic stroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) improved dysphagia outcomes in head and neck cancer patients compared to sham NMES combined with swallow exercises.
results_summary: The active NMES group showed significantly worse Penetration Aspiration Scale scores than the sham group. Both groups reported improved diet and quality of life, but NMES provided no additional benefit over traditional swallow exercises, which were also ineffective alone.
population_specificity: Patients with head and neck cancer experiencing posttreatment dysphagia (moderate to severe cases caused by radiation therapy).

study_goal: To compare the effects of kilohertz-frequency alternating current (KFAC) and low-frequency pulsed current (PC) on quadriceps evoked torque and self-reported discomfort.
results_summary: KFAC and PC showed similar effects on quadriceps evoked torque and self-reported discomfort in healthy individuals. The study concluded that more high-quality RCTs are needed to determine optimal NMES treatment parameters.
population_specificity: Healthy individuals

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a 5-week NMES program versus resistance training (RT) on knee muscle strength in young adults.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference between NMES and RT groups in isokinetic dynamometry, but NMES showed significant increases in peak torque for knee extensors and flexors at different angular velocities, suggesting comparable or potentially superior efficacy to RT with minimal locomotor overload.
population_specificity: 15 students of sport and physical education (age 22 ± 2).
effective_dosage: Not specified (NMES superimposed over voluntary muscle contraction; RT with submaximal loads).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) to a comprehensive pulmonary rehabilitation (cPR) program would enhance clinical-functional outcomes in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in physiological or subjective improvements between NMES + cPR and Sham + cPR groups. In fact, the NMES + cPR group showed smaller increases in exercise capacity (measured by ISWT distance) compared to the Sham + cPR group.
population_specificity: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) patients (n = 27).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the application of neuromuscular ultrasound in assessing ICU-acquired weakness (ICU-AW) and the potential effects of neuromuscular electrical stimulation on muscle preservation.
results_summary: Two studies reported preservation of muscle thickness with neuromuscular electrical stimulation, while one found no preservation. The overall reliability of ultrasound in ICU-AW remains unestablished.
population_specificity: Critically ill patients with ICU-acquired weakness.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether full-movement neuromuscular electrical stimulation reduces spasticity and improves motor function more effectively than control, sensory threshold, and motor threshold stimulation in sub-acute stroke patients.
results_summary: Full-movement neuromuscular electrical stimulation significantly reduced plantar flexor spasticity and improved ankle active dorsiflexion, with effects maintained two weeks post-treatment, but did not improve walking time in the Timed Up and Go Test.
population_specificity: 72 adult patients with sub-acute post-stroke hemiplegia and plantar flexor spasticity.
effective_dosage: 30-minute sessions twice a day, five days per week.

study_goal: To determine if neuromuscular electrical stimulation of the lower trapezius and serratus anterior muscles increases acromiohumeral distance and identify which muscle-group contraction or combination most influences it.
results_summary: Acromiohumeral distance increased during neuromuscular electrical stimulation of the lower trapezius, serratus anterior, and combined muscles, with no significant differences among the three procedures. The results support the importance of scapular muscle force couples in rehabilitation and scapular control.
population_specificity: 20 participants (10 men and 10 women, age 26.9 ± 8.0 years, BMI 23.8) with subacromial impingement syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize clinical and basic research findings on neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) protocols, focusing on their effects on muscle mechanical and physiological outcomes, and provide recommendations for parameter selection in non-neurologic patients.
results_summary: The review highlights gaps in research on NMES for maximizing muscle force, identifies key stimulation parameters for optimizing hypertrophy and force gains, and offers clinical recommendations for different training goals (e.g., force, mass, endurance). It emphasizes the need for more thorough research on NMES protocols for maximal force enhancement.
population_specificity: Non-neurologic, deconditioned patients

study_goal: To determine the effects of 12 weeks of NMES training with ankle weights on intermuscular fascial length and patellar tendon CSA in persons with spinal cord injury.
results_summary: NMES training resulted in a nonsignificant 8% increase in patellar tendon CSA and significant increases in intermuscular fascial length (19% right leg, 23% left leg). Skeletal muscle hypertrophy was associated with increased fascial length.
population_specificity: Seven men with motor complete spinal cord injury.
effective_dosage: Not specified (leg extension weight-lifting program via surface NMES of knee extensor muscle group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if swallow treatment with neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) is more effective than treatment without NMES, and if NMES alone is superior to swallow therapy for post-stroke dysphagia.
results_summary: Swallow treatment with NMES was significantly more effective than treatment without NMES, but NMES alone was not significantly superior to swallow therapy. The results showed high heterogeneity for the first comparison but not for the second.
population_specificity: Post-stroke dysphagia patients.

study_goal: To evaluate the effect of neuromuscular electrical stimulation on lower limb venous blood flow and its potential role in thromboprophylaxis.
results_summary: Neuromuscular electrical stimulation increases venous blood flow and is generally well tolerated, but current evidence does not support its use for thromboprophylaxis. Comparative studies showed DVT incidence ranging from 2% to 50% with stimulation versus 6% to 47.1% in controls.
population_specificity: Varied patient populations across studies (not specified uniformly).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the rehabilitation effectiveness of NMES robot-assisted wrist training versus robot-assisted training alone in chronic stroke patients.
results_summary: NMES robot-assisted training showed more significant improvements in Fugl-Meyer Assessment (shoulder/elbow, wrist/hand) and Action Research Arm Test compared to robot-assisted training alone, along with better reduction in muscle co-contraction.
population_specificity: 26 hemiplegic subjects with chronic stroke.
effective_dosage: 20 training sessions completed within 7 consecutive weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of different electrical stimulation therapies, including Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES), for pain relief in patients with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: NMES was not found to be an appropriate treatment for pain relief in knee osteoarthritis, with interferential current (IFC) showing superior efficacy. The study concluded that none of the interventions, including NMES, were likely to be dangerous.
population_specificity: Patients with knee osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) in improving swallowing function in patients with oropharyngeal dysphagia secondary to acquired brain injury.
results_summary: NMES significantly accelerated swallowing function improvement compared to sham stimulation, with greater increases in functional oral intake scale (FOIS) scores and pharyngeal amplitude contraction. However, both groups showed similar improvements at 3-month follow-up, and tracheal aspiration persisted equally in both groups.
population_specificity: Twenty patients with neurological oropharyngeal dysphagia (14 stroke, 6 severe traumatic brain injury).
study_duration: 1 month of treatment, with follow-up at 3 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the short-term effects of neuromuscular electrical stimulation on muscle size and architecture in children with cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The study found that neuromuscular electrical stimulation increased the cross-sectional area of both the tibialis anterior and gastrocnemius muscles in treated children, while conventional physiotherapy alone showed a decrease in tibialis anterior muscle size. Other measurements did not change significantly in either group.
population_specificity: 28 children diagnosed with spastic diplegic cerebral palsy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effects of NMES on orofacial musculature and assess its potential for treating lingual, labial, and buccal weakness, while identifying future research directions.
results_summary: The study found limited data on NMES for orofacial muscles but highlighted its potential for improving speech intelligibility and swallowing in patients with oral motor weakness. It calls for more experimental studies to investigate NMES's efficacy in this context.
population_specificity: Individuals with lingual, labial, and buccal weakness due to neurological insults.

study_goal: To review the evidence for the use of Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) in critical care patients compared to usual care, evaluating its effects across domains of the ICF framework.
results_summary: NMES showed potential to preserve muscle mass and joint range of motion, improve ventilation outcomes, and reduce activity limitations. Meta-analysis supported NMES for preserving muscle strength, though significant heterogeneity was noted.
population_specificity: Critically ill adult patients in intensive care settings.

study_goal: To investigate the feasibility and preliminary outcomes of a home progressive resistance training program augmented by neuromuscular electrical stimulation in people with multiple sclerosis.
results_summary: The NMES group showed significant improvements in quadriceps endurance, balance, physical impact of MS, and impact of fatigue compared to the PRT group. Participants rated the NMES device as highly usable.
population_specificity: People with multiple sclerosis who use a walking aid (N=37).

study_goal: To analyze the outcomes of neuromuscular electrical stimulation in critically ill patients in intensive care units.
results_summary: Three out of four trials showed significant benefits, including improved peripheral muscle strength, exercise capacity, functionality, and reduced muscle layer thickness loss. The conclusion supports neuromuscular electrical stimulation as beneficial for critically ill patients.
population_specificity: Critically ill patients (ages 52-79) in intensive care units undergoing invasive mechanical ventilation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of neuromuscular electrical stimulation as a behavioral intervention for age-related dysphonia in older adults.
results_summary: The abstract mentions neuromuscular electrical stimulation as one of the voice therapy techniques evaluated, but it does not provide specific findings for this method. The overall evidence for behavioral interventions, including neuromuscular electrical stimulation, is described as inadequate to draw definitive conclusions.
population_specificity: Older adults with age-related voice impairments (presbyphonia).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of traditional swallowing therapy (TS), oropharyngeal neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES), and combined NMES/TS therapy in improving swallowing function in acute stroke patients with dysphagia.
results_summary: Combined NMES/TS therapy showed significant improvements in swallowing function, particularly for solid diets and thick liquids, compared to TS or NMES alone. Both TS and combined therapy improved swallowing according to clinical scales, but combined therapy had superior results in videofluoroscopy assessments.
population_specificity: 29 acute stroke patients with dysphagia

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the inter- and intra-tester reliability of strength measurements during maximal electrically induced contractions (MEIC) using a hand-held dynamometer (HHD).
results_summary: The study found good to excellent inter- and intra-tester reliability for quadriceps femoris muscle strength measurements during MEIC and maximal voluntary isometric contractions (MVIC), but the HHD was not sufficiently reliable for assessing force levels during electrically induced contractions.
population_specificity: Thirty-seven healthy young female adults (mean age 23.4 ± 2.4 years).
effective_dosage: Biphasic pulses (phase duration—300 µs; pulse frequency—75 Hz) at maximally tolerated current level.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) and endurance training (ET) on health-related quality of life, exercise capacity, muscle strength, dyspnea, psychological status, and body composition in patients with severe COPD.
results_summary: NMES significantly improved walking distance, endurance time, psychological status (HADS scores), and most domains of health-related quality of life (SGRQ), with no significant differences compared to endurance training. Both interventions showed comparable benefits in exercise capacity, muscle strength, and body composition.
population_specificity: Patients with severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)

study_goal: To determine the safety and feasibility of neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) in patients during the first five postoperative days after cardiovascular surgery.
results_summary: NMES was safely implemented with high compliance (89.7% completion rate) and no significant adverse effects such as excessive blood pressure changes, heart rate increases, or pacemaker malfunctions. The incidence of atrial fibrillation varied by surgery type (26.9% for coronary bypass, 18.2% for valvular surgery, 20.0% for combined/aortic surgery), but no sustained ventricular arrhythmias occurred.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent cardiovascular surgery, excluding those with peripheral arterial disease, psychiatric/neuromuscular disorders, dementia, severe chronic renal failure, or prolonged mechanical ventilation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the metabolic load and symptom scores of high-frequency (HF-NMES) and low-frequency (LF-NMES) neuromuscular electrical stimulation compared to strength training in individuals with COPD during an eight-week pulmonary rehabilitation program.
results_summary: The study found that metabolic load and symptom scores remained acceptably low over time with increasing training loads during HF-NMES and LF-NMES, though strength training showed higher peak VO2 and VE. Oxygen saturation decreased slightly during HF-NMES and strength training, while heart rate increased in all groups.
population_specificity: 24 individuals with COPD (FEV1: 34 ± 2% predicted, 58% men, age 66 (61-68) years).
effective_dosage: HF-NMES (75 Hz), LF-NMES (15 Hz) (specific duration/frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of neuromuscular electrical stimulation in treating shoulder subluxation in hemiplegic patients.
results_summary: The study found that neuromuscular electrical stimulation can treat shoulder subluxation when administered for 6 hours daily, 5 days a week, over 6 weeks. Taping/strapping for subluxation had conflicting evidence and did not improve upper limb function or range of motion.
population_specificity: Patients with hemiplegia in the upper limb and shoulder complex following a cerebrovascular event.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the hemodynamic effects of Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) and Intermittent Pneumatic Compression (IPC) in improving lower limb venous blood flow for DVT prevention.
results_summary: NMES significantly increased venous blood velocity and ejected blood volume (23.22 ml per cycle vs. baseline 2.52 ml), outperforming IPC by 1.7-3 times in emptying veins and soleal sinuses, key sites for DVT formation. NMES was also noted as silent and portable, addressing usability issues of IPC.
population_specificity: 30 healthy volunteers aged 18-23 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the short-term effects of low-intensity neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) and NMES superimposed onto voluntary contractions (NMES+) on physical performance, muscle cross-sectional area, and daily task capacity in older adults.
results_summary: NMES+ showed significant improvements in mobility, rectus femoris cross-sectional area, and daily task capacity, while NMES alone improved muscle size and daily tasks but not mobility. All intervention groups outperformed the control group.
population_specificity: Older adults aged 75-96 living in a geriatric nursing home, independent in daily activities.
effective_dosage: Intensity set at 40% of one-repetition maximum (1RM) for knee extension exercises.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of an exercise program with and without NMES on pain, functional performance, and muscle strength in knee OA patients immediately posttreatment and 12 weeks after intervention.
results_summary: NMES combined with exercise significantly reduced knee pain immediately posttreatment, but this additive effect was not maintained at 12 weeks. Both groups showed immediate improvements in muscle strength and functional abilities, though some gains (e.g., muscle strength, stair negotiation) were not sustained at follow-up.
population_specificity: 63 participants with knee osteoarthritis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the safety and feasibility of Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) in critically ill patients, particularly its ability to induce adequate quadriceps contraction.
results_summary: NMES was found to be safe with no adverse changes in vital signs or skin reactions. However, only 50% of patients achieved adequate quadriceps contraction in at least 75% of sessions, with sepsis, lower limb edema, and vasopressor use identified as independent predictors of impaired response.
population_specificity: Critically ill patients in medical and surgical ICUs with a prognosticated stay of at least 6 days, excluding those with preexisting neuromuscular disorders or musculoskeletal conditions limiting quadriceps contraction.
effective_dosage: 25 minutes of simultaneous bilateral NMES of the quadriceps femoris muscle, 5 days per week (Monday-Friday).
study_duration: Administered from day 3 to 5 of ICU stay until discharge or up to the study period.
interactions: Vasopressors and sepsis were noted to impair NMES effectiveness.

study_goal: To investigate the applications and effects of neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) in critically ill ICU patients through a systematic review.
results_summary: NMES maintained or increased muscle mass, strength, and volume, reduced mechanical ventilation and weaning time, and increased muscle degradation in ICU patients. A meta-analysis showed significant improvement in quadriceps femoris strength on the MRC Scale.
population_specificity: Critically ill patients in ICU

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether early rehabilitation, including neuromuscular electrical stimulation, during acute admission for chronic respiratory disease exacerbations reduces readmission risk and improves physical performance and health status over 12 months.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in readmission rates or recovery of physical function between the intervention and control groups, with higher mortality observed in the intervention group. Neuromuscular electrical stimulation, as part of the rehabilitation package, did not demonstrate significant benefits over usual care.
population_specificity: Patients aged 45-93 admitted to the hospital with an exacerbation of chronic respiratory disease, predominantly chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (82%).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) or functional electrical stimulation (FES) in improving body composition and metabolic profile in individuals with spinal cord injury (SCI).
results_summary: NMES/FES training significantly increased muscle size but had minimal effects on adipose tissue. Improvements in glucose metabolism, particularly insulin sensitivity, were noted, while effects on lipid profile remained unclear.
population_specificity: Individuals with spinal cord injury (SCI).
effective_dosage: Training frequency ranged from 2 to 5 days/week.
study_duration: Intervention duration varied from 6 weeks to 24 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize existing evidence on the effectiveness and safety of neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) for treating and managing COPD symptoms.
results_summary: NMES was found to be safe for COPD patients and may improve exercise tolerance and quality of life, though more research is needed to confirm these benefits.
population_specificity: Adult participants with diagnosed COPD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) could modify upper esophageal sphincter (UES) dynamics during swallowing.
results_summary: The study found that NMES extended UES relaxation time by 10%, suggesting a modification in UES dynamics and potentially providing more time for bolus passage into the esophagus. Future studies are needed to evaluate this effect in dysphagia patients and its therapeutic benefits.
population_specificity: 26 healthy volunteers
effective_dosage: Stimulation applied above, near, and below the motor threshold (specific amounts not detailed)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the haemodynamic efficacy of a novel neuromuscular electrical stimulation device with intermittent pneumatic compression in healthy subjects.
results_summary: Neuromuscular electrical stimulation significantly increased venous and arterial haemodynamic parameters, outperforming intermittent pneumatic compression in enhancing blood flow and velocity, with benefits lost upon deactivation. It also improved microcirculation in the legs, though hand flux decreased during activation.
population_specificity: Ten healthy volunteers (mean age 27.1 ± 3.8 years, BMI 24.8 ± 3.6 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a novel neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) combined with conventional treatment versus conventional treatment alone in patients with dysphagia after brain injury.
results_summary: The experimental group receiving NMES plus conventional treatment showed more significant improvement in hyoid bone and larynx displacement, VDS-total score, and VDS-pharyngeal score compared to the control group. Both groups improved, but NMES combined with conventional treatment was superior to conventional treatment alone.
population_specificity: Patients with dysphagia after brain injury (n=26, experimental group=12, control group=14).
effective_dosage: NMES at 50 μs pulse duration and 50 Hz frequency, delivered for 40 minutes once daily, 5 days per week.

study_goal: To evaluate the time course of fatigue in torque output and oxygen uptake during isometric subtetanic NMES to inform the design of rehabilitation protocols for accumulating aerobic exercise volume.
results_summary: The study found that subtetanic isometric NMES resulted in a mean oxygen consumption increase of 596 ± 238 mL/min and an average exercise intensity of 3 ± 0.47 metabolic equivalents, with slow declines in oxygen uptake and torque (-0.54% and -0.47% per minute, respectively), suggesting greater sustainability compared to tetanic stimulation.
population_specificity: Healthy men (N=11; mean age 34.2 ± 11.5 years; body mass 79.1 ± 11.7 kg).
effective_dosage: Continuous bilateral isometric quadriceps NMES at 4 Hz, evoking a mean twitch amplitude of 12% of maximum voluntary contraction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether short-term, high-frequency NMES reduces dynamic hyperinflation and improves exercise tolerance, pulmonary function, and quality of life in COPD patients.
results_summary: NMES improved FEV1, FEV1/FVC, exercise tolerance (Tlim and 6-MWD), reduced dyspnea (BDS), enhanced quality of life (SGRQ), lowered TNF-α, and increased β-endorphin levels compared to controls.
population_specificity: Twenty patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
effective_dosage: Bilateral quadriceps stimulation, 5 days/week, twice/day, 45 min/session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the acceptability, safety, and efficacy of NMES in patients with advanced NSCLC undergoing palliative chemotherapy.
results_summary: NMES was not deemed acceptable, with only 50% of eligible patients meeting minimum adherence. No serious adverse events were reported, and no significant differences in muscle strength, lean mass, or physical activity were observed between groups.
population_specificity: Patients with advanced non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) receiving first-line palliative chemotherapy.
effective_dosage: 30-minute sessions, ideally daily but at least three times weekly.
study_duration: Three cycles of chemotherapy (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the clinical efficacy and safety of Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) on quadriceps muscle strength and mass in male soccer players after ACL reconstruction.
results_summary: The study found that NMES was effective in strengthening the quadriceps muscle and restoring muscle mass and strength in soccer players, with no observed pathological changes in knee joint function, indicating safety.
population_specificity: Male soccer players who underwent ACL reconstruction (80 participants: 40 NMES, 40 control).
effective_dosage: Biphasic symmetric rectangular pulses (frequency: 2500 Hz, train of pulses frequency: 50 Hz), applied three times daily (3-hour breaks between treatments), 3 days a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if different electrical stimulation pulse durations (200 or 500 μs) in NMES affected the knee extensor muscle torques subjects tolerated.
results_summary: Subjects tolerated significantly higher torques (49.3% of MVIC) with 500-μs pulses compared to 44.5% with 200-μs pulses. The study suggests that pulse duration may influence NMES efficacy, but further research is needed to assess clinical significance and generalizability.
population_specificity: 15 subjects (specific demographics not provided).
effective_dosage: Monophasic square-wave pulses at 75 pulses per second, with pulse durations of 200 μs or 500 μs, delivered in 1-second trains.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review existing studies on Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) to assess its therapeutic effects for laryngopharyngeal dysfunctions (dysphonia, dyspnoea, dysphagia).
results_summary: The review found mixed results, with some studies reporting favorable outcomes for NMES in dysphagia and vocal fold paresis, while others found no significant benefits. The variability in stimulation protocols and underlying conditions made it difficult to draw definitive conclusions, but NMES appears to be a valuable adjunct in certain cases.
population_specificity: Patients with laryngopharyngeal dysfunctions (dysphonia, dyspnoea, dysphagia) and vocal fold paresis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of functional magnetic stimulation (FMS) for improving swallowing function in poststroke dysphagic patients.
results_summary: FMS significantly improved swallowing speed and capacity in the real group compared to the sham group, with no adverse reactions reported. No significant difference was found in interswallow interval (ISI) between the groups.
population_specificity: Twenty poststroke dysphagic patients aged 51-80 years, with stroke onset 6 to 36 months prior.
effective_dosage: FMS of 30 Hz applied in 20-sec trains for 10 min (total 1200 pulses).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) against active and passive recovery methods between two bouts of maximal aerobic exercise in trained cyclists.
results_summary: NMES was less effective than active recovery (cycling at 30% PVo2max) and comparable to passive recovery (resting) in prolonging time to exhaustion during a subsequent cycling bout. Active recovery showed greater reductions in blood lactate and higher heart rates compared to NMES and passive recovery.
population_specificity: 19 trained male cyclists (28 ± 7 years, 76.4 ± 10.4 kg).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to update the understanding of limb muscle dysfunction in COPD, including emerging therapies like neuromuscular electrical stimulation.
results_summary: The study found that neuromuscular electrical stimulation is an emerging therapy for limb muscle dysfunction in COPD, alongside exercise training, though gaps remain in understanding its mechanisms and optimal use.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) experiencing limb muscle dysfunction.
